description: From Middle English regard, regarde, reguard, from Anglo-Norman reguard, from regarder, reguarder. Attested in Middle English starting around the mid 14th century. Compare guard, reward, guardian, and so on.

entries.meaning: (countable) A steady look, a gaze. [from 15th c.]
examples: He bathed in the memory of her blondness, of her warm blue regard, and the sentiment permeated his sensibility with tenderness made the more rich because its object was someone long since dead.

entries.meaning: One's concern for another; esteem; relation, reference. [from 16th c.]
(preceded by “in” or “with”) A particular aspect or detail; respect, sense. [from 16th c.]
examples: This attempt will be made with every regard to the difficulty of the undertaking  […]

entries.meaning: (uncountable) The worth or estimation in which something or someone is held.
examples: He is held in great regard in Whitehall.

entries.meaning: (Reddit, vulgar) Slang for retard, a very bad stock trader.

description: From Middle English regarden, from Old French regarder, reguarder. First attested in late Middle English, circa the early 15th century.

verbs.description: regard (third-person singular simple present regards, present participle regarding, simple past and past participle regarded)

entries.meaning: To look at; to observe. [from 16th c.]
(transitive) To consider, look upon (something) in a given way etc. [from 16th c.]
examples: I always regarded tabloid journalism as a social evil.
He regards honesty as a duty.
I regard such a way of life with distate.

entries.meaning: (transitive, archaic) To take notice of, pay attention to. [from 16th c.]
(transitive) To have to do with, to concern. [from 17th c.]
examples: That argument does not regard the question.

entries.meaning: (transitive, obsolete) To set store by (something), to hold (someone) in esteem; to consider to have value, to respect. [from 16th c.]
